docs.lead_paragraph: Every time that Marion Nestle sees a new doctor, the awkward question comes up. The doctor looks at her age: 63. The doctor looks at her family history: heart disease. And the doctor asks her why on earth is she not taking estrogen? ''Every encounter with a new doctor involves a discussion about it, not raised by me, raised by the doctor,'' said Dr. Nestle, who is a professor and chairwoman of the department of nutrition and food studies at New York University. ''Are you taking it? Have you considered taking it? At your age, you should be taking it.''
docs.abstract: Analysis of impact of huge federal study of hormone replacement therapy, which has called into question idea that hormones can protect against heart disease, leading killer of women; finding brings to fore great conundrum of American medicine: leading reason for using best-selling drug in country has never been established and might well not be true (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Seven months before Election Day, the struggle over expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs for the elderly is escalating, with both parties maneuvering furiously on an issue that matters, deeply, to a critical group of voters. As the debate over the Republican budget resolution began today in the Senate, for example, Democrats were pushing for an amendment that would require the creation of a Medicare drug benefit before any tax cut could take effect.

headline.main: Bitter Partisan Fight Brewing Over Medicare Drug Benefits

docs.abstract: Partisan struggle over expanding Medicare to cover prescription drugs is escalating, as both parties maneuver furiously on issue of deep importance to crucial group of voters; graphs; Senate begins debate on budget resolution with Democrats proposing amendment that would require Medicare drug benefit before any tax cut; Pres Clinton backs measure; Republican leader Trent Lott says Republicans are committed to benefit; Canadian system is becoming embroiled in debate, as Democratic candidates cross border to showcase lower drug prices; drug industry counters with ads on shortcomings of Canadian health system; Hosue Republicans scramble to produce their own drug plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature agreed today on the outlines of a roughly $77 billion spending plan that generously finances education, health care, transportation and tax cuts, clearing the way for one of the earliest budgets in a decade. With the state running a large surplus, the accord sets the boundaries for a budget that is all but certain to include an array of programs that the governor did not call for in his original budget proposal -- from expansion of prekindergarten classes and reductions in class size to low-cost prescription drugs for the elderly. And state leaders also agreed to let voters decide in November whether to spend money on a host of transportation projects, including a new Second Avenue subway line.

headline.main: ALBANY'S LEADERS REACH AGREEMENT ON SPENDING PLAN

docs.abstract: Gov George Pataki and leaders of New York Legislature agree on outlines of $77 billion-spending plan that generously finances education, health care, transportation and tax cuts, at time when state is running large surplus; state would spend $1.4 billion more than Pataki proposed in January; $1.4 billion in new tax cuts also planned; budget deal is one of earliest in decade, only few days after April 1 deadline; highlights listed; Republican leader Joseph Bruno comments; photo of Democratic Speaker Sheldon Silver (M)
